content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved using java.
At first glance, after reading the conditions, it seems that the task is Easy, but this turns out to be wrong when you start solving it. The puzzle makes you think about the solution, not so long that it gets boring, but enough to be interesting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An interesting puzzle with real world educational value, I really liked it.

Usually accepting puzzles with Unicode strings is discouraged on CG because some of the supported programming languages have poor or no UTF-8 support, so solving this puzzle in any of these programming languages is more challenging (but still possible).

However, Unicode chars are the core topic of this puzzle, so I think it should go ahead. My only concern is that my mother language is not included (despite being in latin script with some extra chars), but I cannot hold a grudge just because of this :-)
The puzzle title is not in proper English. Or is that intentional?

By the way, in italian the letter "J" is considered foreign (exclusions)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_orthography

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved the problem using the inclusion-exclusion rules. The final comment could perhaps be placed at the beginning, stating that there are many ways to determine the language of a text, such as using stopwords. However, in this puzzle, the focus is on the application of rules, etc. My personal opinion is that, being at the end of the text, it almost seems like an alternative way to solve the problem.
I also think it's a medium-level problem, because the problem involves UTF-8 manipulation and the reduction of multiple candidates
Maybe I'm being too cute with the name. Should I just call it Literary Alphabet Soup? Or maybe something completely different.

Hello,

Can you add to the sub-headers of "Language, Exclusions and Inclusions" the exhaustive list of possible letters for exclusions and also for Inclusions?
Tests and their matching validators should be different.  Even just changing the order of the sentences would suffice in my opinion.

* Are the players expected to include "they", "who" and "only" in their solution code? Or are they expected to determine the stop words in each case themselves? Or are stop words totally irrelevant in solving the puzzle?

* The tone of the problem statement feels uncertain in parts, particularly with phrases like "It may seem", "may be used at your discretion" and "potential approaches". This could cause confusion regarding which rules and methods must be implemented in the solution code. I suggest rewriting the instructions so that they sound more certain and direct.

Thanks.
Relegated to a comment, using more direct language, and with explicit approach outlined first.

No worries, I've been working on that before taking it out of Work in Progress. I prefer different quotations to leave no chance of hard coding. There's just one validator left, and finding translations that work is proving a bit tricky. Edit: Done!

I'm not sure what you mean. Are you looking for something like "çøßñğ..."? These all have the distinction of having the Unicode property Alphabetic, so I don't see how such a list would be any more useful. Or are you asking if the lists are exhaustive? Yes, I could state as much for clarity.
Note: A couple of times I've removed questions about difficulty after changing the level. It's now back to medium, which was my original instinct.
Not surprisingly, then, it turns out to not have been used in any of the quotations. Added to exclusions, thanks!
It was an experimental idea and a bit of fun, but maybe not the best. Commented earlier.

While excluding language suggestions where letters aren't single code points, I think ChatGPT must have passed over Hungarian because of the digraphs. But this isn't any different from Spanish ch and rr, so yes it could have been included.

In order to have a better view of the inclusions, I sugest this (sry it's not the same format as the statement):

Language  Exclusions   Inclusions
                                bcfjkqvwxyz çøßñğ[insert exhaustif header]
━━━━━━━━  ━━━━━━━━━━━  ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Danish         q    z   ø  æ  å
Estonian   cf  q wxy     šž  õ            ä  öü
Finnish   b f  q wx                       ä  ö
French                 ç   œ    é    àè  ù ëï ü âêîôû
German                  ß                 ä  öü
Irish        jkqvwxyz          áéíóú
Italian       k  wxy            é    àèìòù
Portuguese    k  w     ç    ãõ áéíóú à          âê ô
Spanish       k  w      ñ      áéíóú          ü
Swedish        q w            å           ä  ö
Turkish        q wx    çğş İı                öü
Welsh        jkqv x z    ŵŷ                     âêîôû
I see. I've put it as a footer. How does that look?
Perfect
Better now. Thank you for the prompt reply.
